{"parsed":{"_path":"/tutorials/longitudinal-analyses-models/mixture-models/growth_mixture_models_tutorial","_dir":"mixture-models","_draft":false,"_partial":false,"_locale":"","title":"Growth Mixture Models (GMM)","description":"","author":"Your Name","format":{"html":{"code-tools":true,"toc":true,"toc-depth":3,"code-link":true,"df-print":"paged"}},"body":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"element","tag":"h3","props":{"id":"Ô∏è-foundations"},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"üèóÔ∏è Foundations"}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"Growth Mixture Models (GMMs) are an extension of latent growth curve models that allow researchers to identify distinct subgroups, or classes, within a population that share similar developmental trajectories over time. Unlike traditional growth models that assume a single homogeneous population, GMMs acknowledge that individuals may follow different patterns of change. By integrating latent class analysis into the growth modeling framework, GMMs simultaneously estimate growth parameters for each class and assign individuals to these latent classes based on their observed data."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"In GMMs, each latent class has its own set of growth parameters‚Äîsuch as intercepts and slopes‚Äîcapturing unique growth trajectories for different subgroups within the data. This approach enables the exploration of heterogeneity in developmental processes, revealing unobserved subpopulations that may differ in their initial status and rates of change. GMMs are particularly useful when there is reason to believe that the population is not uniform in its development, such as when studying diverse responses to an intervention or varying progression of a condition."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"By uncovering distinct growth patterns and estimating the proportion of the population belonging to each class, growth mixture models provide a powerful tool for understanding complex longitudinal data. They allow for the examination of how individual characteristics or covariates influence class membership and growth trajectories within classes. This facilitates more tailored interpretations and interventions by recognizing and modeling the diversity inherent in developmental processes."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"div","props":{"className":["when-to-use-section"]},"children":[{"type":"element","tag":"h3","props":{"id":"when-to-use-growth-mixture-models"},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"ü§î
